newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: HEINEKEN DECLINES COMMENT ON PRIPPS TALK.
newsitem.headline: HEINEKEN DECLINES COMMENT ON PRIPPS TALK.

text.p: Dutch brewer Heineken declined comment on talks it was among main candidates to buy a majority stake in Swedish brewer Pripps-Ringnes from Volvo .
"We're always interested in everything, but do not comment on a specific deal until it is closed," a spokeswoman said.
Volvo earlier declined to comment on a report in Swedish newspaper Dagens Industri that it was selling its 55 percent stake to a foreign brewery.
The Swedish auto maker said in June it regarded Pripps a non-core activity which it aimed to sell before the year-end.
Pripps is 45-percent owned by Norwegian food group Orkla, which also has an option to acquire Volvo's holding in Pripps although it is believed to have insufficient financial muscle to do so.

Pripps makes an operating margin of over 10 percent on annual sales of over 1.5 billion guilders. It has strong market positions in Sweden and Norway, while it is expanding in the Baltic region and in Ukraine.
Heineken said it has growth ambitions in all of Europe, including Scandinavia where it has a small market share with imported premium brands Heineken and Murphy's Irish Stout.
Heineken also targets expansion in Eastern European countries.
In Amsterdam, Heineken shares traded 2.50 guilders higher at 312.80, tracking an upbeat market in mild volume.
Traders on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange said the re-emerged talk of a possible Pripps buy had not triggered many deals.
But a transaction could breath some life into the Dutch blue chip stock which was hit hard last month after Heineken warned full year net profit would be lower than in 1995.
Belgian Interbrew, one of the other possible takeover candidates mentioned in the Dagens Industri report, said it was "still looking at...and investigating" Pripps.
